intro: Halosarcia pluriflora, commonly known as the coastal hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to red. The plant is well adapted to harsh, saline environments and can thrive in coastal areas with high salt exposure. Its root system is deep and extensive, allowing it to access water from deeper soil layers. Halosarcia pluriflora plays an important ecological role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing nectar for pollinators.
